Therefore, we use the classical SV (Wang et al., 2019) to compare accuracy. PCA (Lv et al., 2021) and CGSV (Xu et al., 2021a) represent baseline 2 and baseline 3. Our CoAst (denoted as O). In the CoAst’s experiments, for hyperparameters in Algorithm 1, we set r𝑟r to 10, α𝛼\alpha to 0.02, and N𝑁N to 5.
We set the k𝑘k in Equation 13 to 2.
We report the overall performance in Table 1.
SV, PCA, and CGSV represent baseline 1, baseline 2, and baseline 3, respectively.

S6.T2.caption: Table 2. The effect of the number of subsequent global updates, i.e., k𝑘k, on the contribution assessment’s performance. (C. is short for configuration, and A. is short for Average.)
S6.T2.table:
C. Setting 1: Quantity Setting 2: Noise Setting 3: Resolution Setting 4: Mask
k=1 k=2 k=5 k=10 k=1 k=2 k=5 k=10 k=1 k=2 k=5 k=10 k=1 k=2 k=5 k=10
1 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 0.90 1.00 1.00 1.00
2 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 0.90 0.90 0.90 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00
3 0.80 1.00 1.00 0.90 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 0.10 0.20 0.60 0.50 0.60 0.60 0.60 -0.60
4 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 0.70 0.70 0.70 0.70 0.90 1.00 1.00 1.00
A. 0.95 1.00 1.00 0.98 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00 0.70 0.70 0.80 0.78 0.85 0.90 0.90 0.60
references:
We explore how k𝑘k affects the performance of CoAst.
We perform the experiment with different k𝑘k values, which means that different numbers of global updates are used to assess the local models’ contribution.
We report the results in Table 2.
In different experimental settings, CoAst with k=5𝑘5k=5 reaches the best performance, and the performance of CoAst with k=2𝑘2k=2 is comparable to that of CoAst with k=5𝑘5k=5.
The small and large k𝑘k values, i.e., k=1𝑘1k=1 and k=10𝑘10k=10, have relatively poor performance.
This is because a small k𝑘k value may still let the contribution assessment be affected by stochasticity, while a large value of k𝑘k may make CoAst lack attention to the stochastic gradient descent process.
We recommend setting k𝑘k to 2 or 5 when using our CoAst in practical use.

We report the results of these contrast experiments in Table 3.
By comparing the results of ours and Exp1, we can conclude that increasing the proportion of parameter selection leads to a slight decrease in performance, which is likely due to the noise introduced by the selected parameters.
Our CoAst’s average performance is 0.40625 and 0.25625 higher than Exp2 and Exp3, respectively, indicating that the design of parameter pruning effectively ensures the accuracy of contribution assessment.

S6.T4.caption: Table 4. The effect of update clipping strategy on contribution assessment. We perform the experiment with CIFAR-10 and TinyResNet. We set N𝑁N to 5, and M𝑀M to 100.
S6.T4.table:
α𝛼\alpha Quantity Noise Resolution Mask
0.01 1.00 1.00 0.90 1.00
0.02 1.00 1.00 1.00 1.00
avg 1.00 1.00 0.40 1.00
references:
In the CoAst, we use a hyperparameter α𝛼\alpha (Equation 8) to normalize the local parameter update in each round.
Here we explore how the hyperparameter α𝛼\alpha value affects the contribution assessment effectiveness.
We perform three experiments with CIFAR-10 and TinyResNet.
We set M𝑀M to 100, N𝑁N to 5, and r𝑟r to 10.
In the first two experiments, we set the value of α𝛼\alpha to 0.01 and 0.02, respectively.
In the third experiment, we use an adaptive clipping strategy, where we set α𝛼\alpha as the average value of the selected r% parameters (i.e., 10) of each layer.
We report the results of these three experiments in Table 4.
By comparing the experimental results of the first two experiments, it can be seen that the choice of hyperparameters has little impact on the assessment performance.
However, in the third experiment, the assessment performance decreases.
This is because clipping the parameter update to different values interferes with the assessment process.
In our design, we aim to quantize all parameter updates and assess the contribution based on the direction of the local parameters and global parameter updates.

S6.T5.table:
#Client Quantity Noise
PCA CGSV Ours PCA CGSV Ours
5 -1.00 1.00 1.00 0.30 0.30 1.00
10 0.30 0.99 0.99 0.86 0.88 0.99
#Client Resolution Mask
PCA CGSV Ours FP CGSV Ours
5 0.60 0.30 1.00 0.00 -0.70 1.00
10 0.61 -0.37 0.82 -0.14 -0.96 0.92
references:
Here we explore how the number of clients, i.e., N𝑁N, affects the stability of CoAst.
We experiment with CIFAR-100 and TinyResNet and set k𝑘k to 10 and r𝑟r to 10.
We report the experimental results in Table 5.
When the number of clients increased from 5 to 10, the performance change of Fed-PCA averaged 0.4775, the performance change of CGSV averaged 0.38, and the accuracy change of our method averaged 0.07.
When the number of clients is 5, our CoAst outperforms Fed-PCA and CGSV by an average of 1.025 and 0.5225, respectively. When the number of clients is 10, our CoAst outperforms Fed-PCA and CGSV by an average of 0.775 and 0.795, respectively.
The experimental results fully demonstrate the stability of our method with respect to changes in the number of clients.

S7.T6.caption: Table 6. The performance of the FL model trained in a typical way and our methods. M represents the number of training rounds. (C. is short for configuration.)
S7.T6.table:
C. Typical Ours
M=100 M=100 M=150 M=200
1 0.7963 0.7732 0.7816 0.7880
2 0.4931 0.4456 0.4555 0.4555
3 0.5776 0.5186 0.5590 0.5876
4 0.5767 0.5883 0.5906 0.5906
references:
We report the model performance trained through the typical method and ours in Table 6.
The model trained through the typical method converges after 100 rounds (i.e., M=100𝑀100M=100), while the model trained in our method requires 200 rounds (i.e., M=200𝑀200M=200) to converge.
As can be seen, the performance of the model trained through CoAst outperforms that of the model trained through the typical method at the 100th round only in one case.
When the model converges, the performance of the model trained through CoAst exceeds the model trained in the typical scenario in two cases.
However, experiments in Section 6.2.2 show that weight quantization is important to the accuracy of the assessment since quantization mitigates the negative impact of redundant model parameters on the assessment.
In future work, we will draw on research ideas in model quantization to improve the model performance in accuracy and convergence.
